You failed to mention the bullshit the game sometimes throws at you. Yes I 
enjoy the game very much and it is the best platformer on Wii U but the 
boss battles were in my opinion, a little on the rough side. For a game 
marketed at children as indicated by the age rating of 3 on the box, I 
doubt any children could beat the game. I'm all for a challenging 
experience but even for me the bosses were a bit much. I also thought some 
basic things were out of touch, kong barrels not where you'd like them to 
be and having two checkpoints near each other in an easy section but no 
checkpoints in a hard section of a level.﻿

top_comment.text:
i have a problem with this review. firstly you said that the game's bonus 
minigames are repetitive boring and bad, so why a perfect review score if 
you have a legit gripe? also the gamepad/wii u features arent utilized at 
all, why isn't this a big part of the review? i find this game tedious and 
fustrating more than fun, cheap deaths=/=skill, i feel that it has the same 
issue as mario sunshine, where rather than feeling rewarding with it's 
challenge, it just makes you do trial and error nonsense deaths that make 
you wanna smash your controller, then be RELIEVED when you finish, rather 
than feel rewarded and happy. lastly, this game does not innovate much. i 
think when you weigh in all of the gripes here, it is not deserving of any 
more than a 3/5 maximum, and if you used a scale that uses 0.5 increments, 
maybe even a 2.5. otherwise good review, much more indepth than some other 
video reviews i've seen out there.﻿
top_comment.author: Phoenix Reborn

comments.text:
+GameXplain If I ever try to review games, I think I might go by your score 
system because it's the most impartial I've seen so far. To put my own spin 
on things, though, if I'm disappointed in a game, I'll do an overview of 
how it got to be the way it is from behind the scenes (interviews, 
development details, etc.), factoring that into my final score.

I agree Kitsunex. I'm a veteran to the series and find almost everything in

wasteland :3) very repetitive. I also agree with the "cheap deaths" point.

comments.author: DailyNytemare Man

comments.text:
5 Stars doesn't mean a game's perfect; it just means I loved it. And as I 
mentioned, the bonus rooms are really optional, so I chose to ignore them.

As for the GamePad, I don't feel its use--or lack thereof--is relevant at 
all. What if the game had been released on a system without it? A game 
doesn't have to take advantage of all of a system's features to be good.

Incidentally, I really didn't like Mario Sunshine at all, but I didn't find 
this game to be anywhere close as frustrating--I had fun the entire way 
through. But I did play DKCR before this, so I had a good idea of what was 
in-store =)

*I have a question. If you intend to answer it (THANK UUUUU)  please take 
the whole comment in consideration for your answer.
I have a Wii U, I have the money for it and it looks like a fantastic 
game-but is it too difficult? I'm nowhere near the kind of gamer who enjoys 
a hard game-sure, every once in a while, I like a challenge, but I don't 
want a game where I just get pissed off at W1. I've done my research, and 
my sources say its a hard game, but is it too hard considering that on NSLB 
(New super luigi bros) I only got to the W2 boss before I just ragequit in 
frustration? I get that the later worlds will be far from a cinch, but 
again: IS it too hard?
BASICALLY: I just want to know, out of 12, how hard it is.*﻿
top_comment.author: Tepis Inferno

comments.text: +MacJulian88 Ok thanks dude that rly helps :D ^^
comments.author: Tepis Inferno

comments.text:
Depends on what your objective is... If you aim to collect everything for a 
perfect score without running out of lives at any point, forget about it.
It's a mildly challenging game in the beginning, again, depending on 
whether you are a completionist, but gets to be very challenging near the 
end (that's disregarding any completionist ambitions) and ends in some of 
the hardest levels and demanding / frustrating boss fights ever.

You will enjoy the experience and feel incredibly accomplished once you 
beat the game.
If you ragequit easily, chances are you'll have your fun with it until it 
becomes too challenging and will probably never even get halfway through 
it. In that case I'm not sure it'd be worth the full retail price and you 
might want to look for special offers.
Do I recommend giving it a shot even if you end up sucking at it? Hell 
yeah! At least rent it - you're missing out.
comments.author: MacJulian88

+SethMtv 3D World? I have almost 60 hours playtime on it, so yeah. The 
first three-four worlds are cool designed, but a little easy! As you reach 
the bonus levels after world 8, it becomes really hard, with awesome 
levels! Around 10-15 hours of the playtime might be from playing with 
friends and family, but that still leaves 45 hours. The only other games 
I've played more than that is Nintendo Land (100) and NSMBU (with the NSLU 
DLC, 80 hours). I also got Pikmin 3 on 45 hours.

superior in every way!  Agree a little bit on the NSMB-games. The series is 
stale, and is too afraid to try new things. But while the three first had 
mostly bad level design (NSMB2, I'm looking at you) NSMBU is up with Mario 
World in my eyes! It still plays it a little bit too safe, but it's a major 
step up from the rest of the series!

top_comment.author: sdw4527

comments.text:
I am definitely satisfied with the amount of content.  Now, if someone just 
sort of speeds through the main game, I could see someone thinking it is a 
bit on the short side.  But, if one takes the time to really ‘chew’ on the 
game, you will be MORE than satisfied, I think.  So, here is basically how 
it has worked for me:  I played through the main game.  Then (and I’m still 
doing this actually), I started back on Island #1 to unlock the extra 
levels.  I think there are like 3 levels to unlock on Island #1 alone…and 
these are not like the unlockable levels from other games that tend to be 
short and just tacked on.  The extra levels here are JUST as good and long 
as the main levels.   It can take a lot of time and effort to get the extra 
levels, so there is a lot of playtime there.  Then, you’ll want to play 
each level for the KONG letters and the puzzle pieces, and at least attempt 
to get a medal on the speed runs.  So, my point is that if you really take 
your time with the game, try to be complete and really savor what is there, 
you’ll absolutely love it and you won’t feel cheated in the slightest.  I 
am a HUGE DKC fan from the first game to today…and this game, overall, is 
my favorite.  Absolutely LOVE it!
comments.author: Brent Kaseman

comments.text:

comments.author: WiiManElite

comments.text:
+GameXplain I know, but I can't enjoy a game if it says that I'm missing 
collectibles in a level or after beating a game it says that I've only 
completed 60% of it on the file select screen. That's just my OCD. 
Collectibles are one of my biggest problems with modern platformers. So 
many games that people love like Donkey Kong Country Returns, Rayman 
Origins, and Sonic Colors, I haven't been able to enjoy because looking for 
collectibles in those games ruins the pace and fluidity of them, and I just 
can't feel satisfied if I don't collect them. I wish platformers would go 
back to the way they used to be, where you felt good about finding secrets 
because you needed the extra lives/power ups you would find, not because 
there was one of several arbitrary collectibles of that level. A lot of 
people say that they help give a game replay value, but I say the opposite 
is true. When I go to replay a level, half the things in the level lead to 
collectibles you've already gotten, so in turn, half the level becomes 
pointless!
comments.author: Caeden Hart

Nintendo took it all casual and I hate that, so i agree with you there.
As for the difficulty curve, after you beat the game and get special world, 
the first few levels are instantly a bitch to complete in comparison, like 
the one with the 3d land green platforms, the cannon boxes and the 
flip-switches you have to hit before falling to your doom, try that with 
2-3 players.
Its inconsistant and frankly, lost, while the game is one of my favourites, 
and the game is outstanding, difficulty is just messed up. Nintendo are 
dealing with 2 different audiences and its not working.
DK on the other hand is challenging from the start, and has a very nice 
curve to it, for that, i place it above mario 3d world too,
Me and my friends both say "It only gets kinda hard around half way through 
world 7" to almost every modern mario.
But some levels even seem out of place, take the grumplump or whatever, the 
block that rolls in lava when you step on it, it in ONE level, and its hard 
as all fuck in 2 player... in a world where we died 0 times.
comments.author: MysteriousStranger50

comments.text:
After New Super Mario Bros. DS, the Mario games started to become easier 
and childish and I started losing hope for the Mario games to be like Super 
Mario 64. Super Mario 3D World, only in my opinion, was only impressive 
visually. After about 5 minutes of playing it myself, it felt like Super 
Mario 3D Land and New Super Mario Bros. Wii and I never touched it again. 
Uninspiring only in my opinion. Donkey Kong Country Returns was very 
challenging and I could never get passed World 1. Donkey Kong Tropical 
Freeze however, looks both easy to pick up and get going AND visually 
impressive. I hope to get my hands on this game and I also hope it is 
satisfying. This is just my opinion AND MY OPINION ONLY! So don't get mad 
if any of your opinions are different from mine.:/

captions.text:
You know, for as excited as DK is to dig into
his banana cake here, it still pales in comparison

to how excited I was to play DKC: Tropical
Freeze.

And with that excitement came some pretty
some pretty high expectations. After all,

I'm a huge fan of the original series on the
Super Nintendo, and I found DKCR to be one

of the Wii's best games. So yeah, my expectations
for the sequel were pretty high. And yet,
Tropical Freeze completely shattered them.

Now part of what made Donkey Kong Country
Returns such a memorable experience was how

dynamic the levels were--which is a tradition
Tropical Freeze not only continues, but somehow

improves upon. The levels in this game are
so full of life and personality that they're

essentially characters in and of themselves.
Take Grassland Grove, for example, which involves

navigating an entire environment that dances
to the music, such as the trees early into

the level, and even animal puppets that you'll
catch a ride later on.

Then there's Sawmill Thrill--a minecart level--where
a giant sawblade literally carves the path

from wood in front of your very eyes. Wait,
did I say a minecart level? Because it turns

into a toboggan one about halfway through.
These levels are changing. All. The. Time.

The amount of stuff happening in every level
is simply unparalleled for any platforming

game that I've played. Take World 3's Bramble
Scramble, where the plant-based platforms

actually grow into place while you're traversing
the level. Even the levels that are literally
set in stone, really aren't.

It constantly changing levels add a sense
of hyper-realism to the game that, frankly,

makes the levels of most other platformers
seem dull by comparison. There's a sense of

real energy here--a sense that anything can--and
often will--happen.

And adding to this all is the introduction
of a highly dynamic camera during some parts

of the game, such as during a few barrel-blasting
sequences, or in some minecart levels. It

provides both a fresh--and much more cinematic
perspective--and even opens up some unique

gameplay opportunities, like being able to
hop between tracks. Although I do have two

complaints. For one, It can be a bit little
tricky to gauge depth in these scene, that

might result in some questionable deaths.
And 2) The dynamic camera pops up a lot less

frequently than I expected and I would have
loved to have seen more. But really, that's

kind of of like complaining that there's too
few sprinkles on an otherwise delicious cake

When you get down to it, nearly every single
level in Tropical Freeze feels completely

distinct from the others. So much so, that
I could describe just about any level in the

game using just a few words, and anyone who's
played the game would have no trouble figuring
out which level I was talking about.

Unfortunately, it's this very amount of diversity
that makes my biggest complaint about the

game all the more painful. The dreaded bonus
rooms from Donkey Kong Country Returns are

back. Okay, so maybe they're not *that* bad,
but the problem is that they all end up feeling

basically the same, involving collecting bananas
before time runs out in order to earn a puzzle

piece. And since you might encounter at least
1 or 2 in every level, they can get tiresome
very quickly.

Not only are they repetitive--especially if
you played the previous game--but they kind

of ruin the flow of these otherwise fantastically
crafted levels. Now let me stress that it's

not really a huge problem--particularly as
they are optional, and only need to be explored

if you're trying to 100% the game. But it
is a blight on an otherwise near-perfect experience,

and I would actually encourage you to skip
them on your first play-through in order to

fully experience the levels themselves as
they should be.

Thankfully, Tropical Freeze did remove one
of the more annoying aspects of the original

game, which was the blowing mechanic, which
is now replaced with the far quicker--and

context-dependent pulling mechanic, which
greatly improves the game's pace if you are
seeking collectibles.

Another major addition are the underwater
levels--yep, the giant ape finally learned

to swim...again. Now I'm normally not a huge
fan of underwater levels--and while Tropical

Freeze's are still on the lower end of my
list of "favorite levels from the game"--they're

still among the best swimming levels I've
played. And this is largely due to the fantastic

controls--somehow, Retro managed to make a
giant swimming ape feel...graceful?

But a large part of what makes the swimming
levels--and all the levels in general--so

enjoyable, is just how atmospheric they are.
The way the visuals and music work together

with the gameplay to bring these levels to
life is nothing short of sublime. Let's just

soak in the wonder of Grassland Grove for
a few moments.

Man, I almost feel bad having to interrupt
it!

Not only is this game gorgeous, but the soundtrack
is simply brilliant. Although I enjoyed the

music in DKCR, it fell short of the high-standards
set by the games predecessors--a standard

that Tropical Freeze manages to live up to,
which is no doubt in part due to having one

of the series's original composers, David
Wise, return.

Now there is one major new feature that I
haven't mentioned yet--which is a little surprising

considering its prominence in the game. And
that's the fact that you can now choose between

one of three different partner characters,
being Diddy, Dixie, and Cranky--each of which

brings a grants DK a different ability. Diddy
allows you to hover in the air briefly, while

Dixie allows you to essentially perform a
double-jump for even more hang-time, while

Cranky uses his cane allowing you cross hazardous
terrain.

But here's the thing: the 3 characters aren't
really created equal. In fact, I couldn't

find a single reason to ever use Diddy Kong,
besides for nostalgia's sake, because Dixie

seems to be better in every way, allowing
you to fly much further than Diddy can. And

while Cranky's ability is occasionally useful,
its far too situationally-dependent to be

of use most of the time. So for the bulk of
the experience, I ended up using Dixie. Now

this isn't really a complaint--I mean, it
certainly didn't dampen my enjoyment of the

game any. But it is a little odd that the
game introduces a pretty big feature that

ultimately didn't end up mattering much, in
my experience at least.

Now speaking of characters, I did want to
touch on the new enemies introduced in this

game briefly: the Nomads. I found the fusion
of vikings with arctic-animals to be a lot

more personable than the Tikis featured in
DKCR, and really serve as a decent Kremling

replacement. Even the boss fights this time
around are a lot more creative than before

All in all, Donkey Kong Country: Tropical
Freeze isn't just the best platformer I've

played in the last 3-years--it's also the
best game currently available on the Wii U.

Period. If you're old enough to have played
the original series, it really is the Donkey

Kong Country 2 to the original game. That
is to say that, although it's not as ground-breaking

as the first, it more than makes up for it
by improving upon the original experience

in every conceivable. It's simply a beautiful
experience from beginning to end that that

consistently delivers surprises around every
corner. Which is why I'm giving Donkey Kong

Country: Tropical Freeze a full 5 Stars out
of 5. Thanks for watching and make sure to

stay-tuned to GameXplain.com for more on DKC:
Tropical Freeze and other things gaming too!

title: Donkey Kong Country: Tropical Freeze - Video Review (Wii U)
